questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is sent to the hospital from a nursing home after 2 days of fever, confusion, and lethargy. The patient has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Her temperature is 38.8 C (102 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 116/min. She has mild suprapubic and right costo-vertebral angle tenderness. Her leukocyte count is 18,000/mms, and urinalysis is consistent with acute cystitis. A femoral venous access is planned for administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics. The femoral artery pulsation is palpable immediately below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following describes the optimal cannulation site for the femoral vein?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately lateral to the femoral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately medial to the femoral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Midway between the iliac crest and the femoral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Superior and medial to the pubic tubercle

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediately medial to the femoral artery

questions.text: A 2 day old neonate born to a 30 year old female develops persistent bilious vomiting. Laparotomy performed after initial work up reveals that the cecum is fixed to the right upper abdominal quadrant. Which of the following embryologic processes most likely failed in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds

options.label: C
options.text: Hindgut descent along the inferior mesenteric artery

options.label: D
options.text: Midgut rotation around the superior mesenteric artery

questions.correct_answer: D. Midgut rotation around the superior mesenteric artery

questions.text: A 45 year old female, went for a checkup, when she noticed several lumps in her anterior neck region. She had these lumps over the period of three years. Full physical examination was done. Malignancy was suspected on fine needle aspiration. Thyroidectomy was proposed. On the operating table, while ligating superior thyroid artery , the surgeon accidentally severs a nearby nerve. Which muscle will be denervated, as a result ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery and vein , the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is at risk of injury during thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old came to OPD with pain in the right ear. He is a swimming coach and spends most of his time in the swimming pool. Irritation to which of the following structure causes fainting while inserting a speculum into the external auditory meatus, when the patient has an external ear infection?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Small auricle nerve branch of vagus nerve innervates the posterior external audiotry canal and when stimulated causes vasovagal syncopal episode. (decrease in blood pressure and heart rate)

questions.text: All of the following cervical Somites (Myotomes) contribute to the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm, except?

On a busy day in the emergency bay, your wife brought your 4 year old child. When you attended them your son was holding his right upper extremity at his side with his elbow extended and forearm pronated. Any motion of the right elbow produces pain. (-) visible bruises or edema. Your son mumbled that he was playing ‘ring-a-ring-a-rosies’ in the park with other kids and fell down. Which structure is most likely injured in your son ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Sudden traction on the outstretched and pronated arm of a child results in the radial head subluxation. (nursemaid’s elbow). the annular ligament is displaced and torn in this injury.

questions.text: A lesion or injury to the marked nerve (arrow) will result in ?

A well known Neuro-Endocrinologist, 60 year old male, came to the emergency bay due to fever, chills and malaise. He states that his intuition says that there is a heart pathology and requests you to evaluate his cardiac parameters first. Physical examination revealed a new holosystolic heart murmur that radiates towards the axilla. Blood cultures were obtained. He underwent transesophageal echocardiography. The ultrasound probe was placed in the mid-esophagus facing anteriorly and the cardiac chambers were interrogated. Which of the following chambers is closest to the probe, anatomically ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The left atrium forms up the majority of the posterior surface of the heart.

questions.text: You were in your weekly family gathering after a very long time. Your uncle who is healthy and has no significant past medical history complains of chronic abdominal pain. All of a sudden he grabbed his tummy and cried out in pain. You took him to the hospital and there , CT of the abdomen was done (given below). which of the following, is consistent with the marked structure in the image ?

options.label: A
options.text: It joins the splenic vein to form the portal vein

options.label: B
options.text: It is formed by the union of the common iliac veins

options.label: C
options.text: It gives rise to the right and left renal arteries

options.label: D
options.text: It drains through the cystic duct into the common bile duct

questions.correct_answer: B. It is formed by the union of the common iliac veins
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The right and left common iliac veins merge together to form the IVC at the level of L4-L5. The renal arteries and veins lie at the level of L1.

questions.text: There is a stab wound at the fifth intercostal space along the midclavicluar line. The victim is conscious but in distress. Which structure is most likely be punctured ?

A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of exertional chest pain. He first noticed the pain a couple of months ago when he was shoveling debris off his driveway and has since experienced several episodes while doing other strenuous tasks. He describes the pain as a heavy crushing sensation and says it is relieved with rest. The patient undergoes coronary angiography and is found to have severe stenosis of the right coronary artery and left anterior descending and circumflex arteries. He is referred to a surgeon for coronary artery bypass grafting. During the procedure, a portion of his great saphenous vein is removed and grafted to one of the diseased coronary arteries to bypass its atherosclerotic narrowing. The vein used as a graft during this patient's procedure can be accessed at which of the following sites?

options.label: A
options.text: At midline of the popliteal fossa

options.label: B
options.text: Just inferior to the anterior superior iliac spine

options.label: C
options.text: Just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle

options.label: D
options.text: Just superior to the inguinal ligament

questions.correct_answer: C. Just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle

questions.text: A 25 year old female is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient presents with severe bleeding from her left hand due to a penetrating injury in the “anatomical snuff box’’ region. The patient is alert and conscious. Her temperature is 98.6 F, pulse is 98 bpm, blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg and respirations are 15/min. The artery responsible for bleeding in this patient is ?

A 34 year old male was brought to the emergency department after being involved in a road traffic accident. He suffered blunt trauma and bilateral femur fractures. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and pulse is 110/min. During resuscitation, he received several units of packed red blood cells. Once stabilized, patient started complaining of tingling sensation in his toes and fingers. His serum calcium level noted to be 7.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the likely cause of patient’s current symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renal tubular secretion of calcium

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium chelation by a substance in the transfused blood

options.label: C
options.text: Electrolyte leakage from red blood cells during pre-transfusion storage

options.label: D
options.text: Antibody mediated red blood cell membrane damage

questions.correct_answer: B. Calcium chelation by a substance in the transfused blood
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ LEARNING OBJECTIVE –

questions.text: A 40-year-old female, with a long history of menorrhagia, came to the physician with low levels of hemoglobin identified by routine lab investigation. She was diagnosed to have iron deficiency anemia and started on ferrous sulfate. After 3 months of therapy, her lab values have improved. She now asks about stopping her supplements as she is concerned about iron buildup and damage to vital organs. The doctor reassures her that iron hemostasis is maintained by multiple cells in the body. Which of the following cells secrete a substance that controls iron storage and release by other cells involved in iron hemostasis?

A 5 year old boy, is bought to the physician with jaundice and pallor for a very long time. He was adopted at the age of 1 year, and hence family history is unknown. Laboratory studies done, showed anemia, reticulocytosis and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells without central pallor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration

questions.text: A 25 year old female, came to medicine OP with complaints of chronic fatigue. She has a history of heavy menstrual periods since menarche and also has frequent nosebleeds as a child. Her past medical history is otherwise insignificant and takes no medications. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, a mean corpuscular volume of 72 fl and decreased levels of von Willebrand factor in serum. The protein normally binds to which of the following?

A 14-year-old girl from Gujarat was rescued after a major earthquake. She was initially treated for minor injuries and dehydration but was referred for further investigations due to persistently low blood pressure (95/44 mm Hg). A continuous machinery-like murmur was heard upon auscultation of her chest. An ECG and an echocardiogram revealed left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities is most likely to be present?

A 78-year-old male presents for a routine checkup. His blood pressure is 180/70 mmHg, and his heart rate is 75/min. Physical examination findings are unremarkable. The doctor explains to the patient that his hypertension is most likely caused by age-related _________?

The research division of a large pharmaceutical company focuses on their efforts on studying renal tubular transport proteins. A substance is identified that specifically and completely inhibits glucose transport in the proximal renal tubules. In a healthy volunteer receiving the substance, glucose clearance will best approximate the clearance of which of the following?

A new dialysis technique is developed to clear circulating autoantibodies from plasma. The technique is based on using a semipermeable membrane. Which of the following is most likely to increase the rate of dialysis?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase surface area of the membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Applying negative charge to the membrane

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase surface area of the membrane

questions.text: A 40 year old male is diagnosed with hepatic cirrhosis due to prolonged heavy alcohol consumption. He develops massive ascites and low extremity edema that responds well to furosemide therapy. However, a week later the patient receives high dose ibuprofen for joint pains and soon develops worsening abdominal distension. Blunting of the diuretic response in this patient is due to interruption of which of the following substances?

A 40 year old male, came to the emergency department with complaints of one episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding at home two hours back. He is unable to provide any information, but his medical records show history of alcoholism. After undergoing emergency evaluation and appropriate resuscitation, his condition stabilizes. Gastric lavage was done, which initially contained blood, but then cleared quickly. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, which showed a linear mucosal tear at the gastrointestinal junction. The process directly responsible for causing this tear, will most likely result in which of the following acid base disturbance?

A 40 year old male, came to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and improved on bending forward. Physical examination shows vitals are stable, abdominal examination reveals tenderness over epigastrium and decreased bowel sounds. The patient is admitted and started with IV fluids and analgesics, but the condition did not improve. Hence, abdominal CT scan done which shows diffuse pancreatic enlargement with areas of necrosis. The inappropriate activation of which of the following enzymes has created this condition?

A 50 year old male, with history of hepatitis C infection, was brought to the emergency department by his wife after several episodes of vomiting bright red blood. He was admitted to the hospital and appropriate treatment was started. During morning rounds the next day, the treating physician found that the patient is disoriented and cannot identify the date/day or the current location. Physical examination done shows significant abdominal distention and gynecomastia. Repetitive flicking motions of the hands are seen when the patient is asked to outstretch his arms and dorsiflex his wrists. Which of the following event is the most likely precipitant of the patient’s altered mental status?

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased concentration of gamma aminobutyric acid

options.label: D
options.text: Increased load of nitrogenous substance absorbed by the gut

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased load of nitrogenous substance absorbed by the gut
questions.explanation:
Stage

Symptoms

I

Mild Confusion, agitation, irritability, sleep disturbance, decreased attention

II

questions.text: 25-year-old male seeks evaluation for increased fatigue and muscle aches during exercise. He stated that recently he joined an exercise program to lose weight. Stress testing reveals normal cardiac function, but serial blood tests show increased serum lactic acid and ammonia levels when he was at rest. His physician postulates a mitochondrial DNA depletion disorder that affects mitochondrial function due to defects in mitochondrial DNA polymerase or tRNAs. Which of the following options: (1) list mitochondrial pathways that would explain the man’s blood findings, and (2) name a compound linking these pathways?

options.label: C
options.text: Citric acid cycle, electron transport, and isocitrate

options.label: D
options.text: Citric acid and urea cycles, and fumarate

questions.correct_answer: D. Citric acid and urea cycles, and fumarate

questions.text: A 26-year-old medical student contracts a skin infection from an elderly patient and notes expanding circular red lesion on the thigh at dinner that night. He places a warm washrag on the lesion at bedtime and awakens with shortness of breath. After reluctantly going to health clinic, he faints during the registration process and awakens in ICU. The attending physician tells him he has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus with toxic shock syndrome and adult respiratory distress syndrome. He wishes to use a new antibiotic that acts on the earliest step of protein synthesis. Which of the following steps are targeted?

options.label: B
options.text: Loading of the small ribosomal subunit with initiation factors, messenger RNA, and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Sliding of the ribosome three bases forward to read a new codon

options.label: D
options.text: Binding of the small ribosomal subunit to the large ribosomal subunit

questions.correct_answer: B. Loading of the small ribosomal subunit with initiation factors, messenger RNA, and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA

questions.text: A coal mine worker was brought in an unconscious state to the emergency room after a blast in the mine. His blood Carboxyhemoglobin level was high and he was diagnosed with CO poisoning. CO is a known inhibitor of the electron transport chain. Which complex of electron transport chain is inhibited by CO?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option A: Complex I is one of the main sites at which premature electron leakage to oxygen occurs, thus being one of the main sites of the production of superoxide.
  • ↳ Option B: Complex II is a parallel electron transport pathway to complex 1, but unlike complex 1, no protons are transported to the intermembrane space in this pathway. Therefore, the pathway through complex II contributes less energy to the overall electron transport chain process.
  • ↳ Option C: The complex III is inhibited by dimercaprol, Napthoquinone, and Antimycin.

questions.text: A- 29 year- old hotel worker presented to emergency department complaining of chills and breathing difficulty. He was a heroin abuser who was admitted in the same hospital 7 years ago because of drug over dosage. He had lost 10 kg of body weight since his last clinical visit. On examination, he had multiple enlarged lymph nodes. Several red nodules were there on the chest and arms. His body temperature was 40oC, B.P. 170/50 mm Hg and respiration was shallow with a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute. The chest radiograph showed diffuse pneumonia. Sputum smear revealed numerous Pneumocystis organisms while skin biopsy revealed Kaposi’s sarcoma. The patient is diagnosed with AIDS. What is the specific exam to diagnose AIDS?

options.label: B
options.text: Diminished cell-mediated immunity as indicated by skin tests

options.label: C
options.text: Lymph node biopsy shows profound abnormalities

questions.text: A 65- year –old patient presents with weight loss, loss of appetite, dull dragging pain in the right hypochondrium and jaundice from the last 1 month. Stool is reported to be clay colored from the same duration. Blood biochemistry reveals Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Urine shows the presence of bilirubin. The patient has been diagnosed with carcinoma of head of the pancreas. Which serum enzyme is expected to be much higher than normal for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Alanine Transaminase (ALT):

 

Produced in hepatocytes

 

 

 

 

Very specific marker of hepatocellular injury

 

 

 

Relatively low concentrations in other tissues so more specific than AST

 

Levels fluctuate during the day

 

 

 

Rise may occur with the use of certain drugs or during periods of strenuous exercise.

Aspartate Transaminase (AST):

 

Occurs in two isoenzymes, indistinguishable on standard AST assays.

 

 

 

The mitochondrial isoenzyme is produced in hepatocytes and reacts to membrane stresses in a similar way to ALT.

 

The cytosolic isoenzyme is present in skeletal muscle, heart muscle and kidney tissue.

 

Caution must be exercised in its use to evaluate hepatocellular damage.

 

 

Usually rises in conjunction with ALT to indicate hepatocellular injury: a hepatitis picture.

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP):

 

A group of isoenzymes that act to dephosphorylate a variety of molecules throughout the body.

 

Produced in the membranes of cells lining bile ducts and canaliculi.

 

 

Released in response to the accumulation of bile salts or cholestasis.

 

 

Non-hepatic production in the kidney, intestine, leukocytes, placenta and bone.

 

Physiological rise in pregnancy or in growing children.

 

 

Pathological rise in Paget’s disease, renal disease and with bone metastases.

Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT):

 

Present in liver, kidney, pancreas and intestine.

It is found in the microsomes of hepatocytes and biliary epithelial cells.

Elevation of GGT in association with a rise in ALP is highly suggestive of a biliary tract obstruction and is known as a cholestatic picture.

Subject to rise with hepatic enzyme induction due to chronic alcohol use or drugs such as rifampicin and phenytoin.

questions.text: A 23 –year-old young woman, who recently began taking birth control pills, presents to emergency room with cramping abdominal pain, anxiety, hallucinations and paranoid behavior. A surgical evaluation, including Ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scan have failed to demonstrate any abdominal process. Examination reveals vesicles and bullae on the skin of arms and face. Urine analysis reveals the presence of porphyrins (ALA, PBG, Uro and Coproporphyrins). What is the possible diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Variegate porphyria (VP) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder due to partially deficient activity of the mitochondrial enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX) . VP is both a cutaneous porphyria (with chronic blistering skin lesions) and an acute porphyria (with severe episodic neurovisceral symptoms).In adult-onset cutaneous blistering lesions (sub epidermal vesicles, bullae, and erosions that crust over and heal slowly) of sun-exposed skin, especially the hands and face. Facial hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis may occur. Acute neurovisceral symptoms can occur any time after puberty, are highly variable, but may be similar from episode to episode in a patient with recurrent attacks. Symptoms may become chronic. The most common manifestations are abdominal pain, constipation, tachycardia, hypertension, pain in the back, chest, and extremities, anxiety, agitation, seizures, and neuromuscular weakness that may progress to quadriparesis and respiratory paralysis. The biochemical diagnosis of VP is established in an individual with elevated urine porphobilinogen (PBG) or porphyrins and a fluorescence peak at ~626 nm on plasma fluorescence scanning The molecular diagnosis of VP is established by identification of a heterozygous pathogenic variant in PPOX on molecular genetic testing.
  • ➤ Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP )characteristically demonstrate acute episodes of neurovisceral symptoms but may not manifest fully for a long time. AIP manifests as episodes of abdominal pain, neuropathies, and constipation, but, unlike most other porphyrias, patients with AIP do not develop a cutaneous rash. The primary enzymatic defect in AIP is the deficiency of porphobilinogen - deaminase, also called hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS), the third enzyme in heme synthesis. The acute attacks of AIP are a result of the uncontrolled upregulation of the ALA synthase enzyme. The diagnosis of AIP gets delayed due to nonspecific symptoms and similarities with other diseases. The only cure is orthoptic liver transplantation.
  • ➤ Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder by markedly reduced enzyme activity of uroporphyrinogen III synthase, characterized in most individuals by severe cutaneous photosensitivity with blistering and increased friability of the skin over light-exposed areas. Onset in most affected individuals occurs at birth or early infancy. The first manifestation is often pink-to-dark red discoloration of the urine. Repeated light exposure can lead to scarring, infection and loss of facial features and digits.
  • ➤ Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP) is an acute (hepatic) porphyria in which the acute symptoms are neurovisceral and occur in discrete episodes. Attacks typically start in the abdomen with low-grade pain that slowly increases over a period of days (not hours) with nausea progressing to vomiting. In some individuals, the pain is predominantly in the back or extremities. When an acute attack is untreated, a motor neuropathy may develop over a period of days or a few week. Acute hepatic porphyria should be suspected in individuals with the following symptoms or findings are Nausea for at least 48 hours, Abdominal, back, or extremity pain for at least 48 hours, New-onset seizures, Hyponatremia, Family history of porphyria. The most sensitive and specific biochemical screening test for any one of the acute porphyrias (including HCP) during an acute attack is a striking increase in urinary porphobilinogen. Quantitative analysis of porphyrins in both urine and feces is essential to distinguish between the different acute porphyrias and establish the diagnosis of HCP.
  • ➤ Learning objectives: The porphyria diseases are a group of metabolic disorders caused by abnormal functioning of heme biosynthesis enzymes and characterized by the excessive accumulation and excretion of porphyrins and their precursors. Precisely which of these chemicals builds up depends on the type of porphyria. Porphyria is not a single disease but a group of nine disorders. Each porphyria results from overproduction of heme precursors secondary to partial deficiency or, in XLP, increased activity of one of the enzymes of heme biosynthesis.

questions.text: A middle aged women on oral contraceptives for many years developed neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness and mental confusion. Her hemoglobin level was 8g/dl. Biochemical investigations revealed that she was excreting highly elevated concentrations of xanthurenic acid in urine. She also showed high levels of triglycerides and cholesterol in serum. All of the above findings are most probably due to deficiency of vitamin b6 caused by prolonged use of oral contraceptives except?

options.label: B
options.text: neurological symptoms by decreased synthesis of biogenic amines

questions.correct_answer: D. increased triglyceride and cholesterol levels

questions.text: A 4-year-old child showing symptoms of muscle pain and weakness after playing is taken to the hospital for examination. Tests reveal slight hepatomegaly and cardiomegaly. Biopsy of liver shows extreme but nonspecific fatty changes, and a muscle biopsy showed large amounts of cytoplasmic vacuoles filled with neutral lipid. Fasting for a period of 24 hours resulted in blood glucose levels drop without a corresponding production of ketone bodies. The pH of the blood is normal. Which of the following is the best diagnosis for this child’s problems?

A 44-year-old male is concerned about his risk of a heart attack since his brother just had a heart attack at the age of 46. His physician orders an HbA1C, lipid panel, and homocysteine level. The biochemical examination of blood shows normal Hb1AC levels and normal lipid profile but higher than normal homocysteine levels. Which one of the following amino acids is not properly formed in his body?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ As this patient has no genetic enzyme deficiencies so the most probable cause of his homocystinuria is deficiency of vitamins which can be treated by vitamin supplementation. All other amino acids given in options do not require homocysteine for their synthesis.

questions.text: A 11 month old boy weighing 3kg presented with polyuria, polydipsia and delayed motor milestones. Physical examination revealed alert, awake, not in respiratory distress , afebrile, blood pressure was 95/58. Blood investigation was done. It shows PH of 7.46, creatinine of 0.5mg/dl, potassium of 3mEq/l, sodium of 125mEq/l, chloride of 88mEq/l, calcium of 8.8mg/dl, bicarbonate of26mEq/l. Ultrasonography shows medullary nephrocalcinosis. The most likely diagnosis is

A man 63 yr old was reported dead. He was admitted with a history of worsening congestive heart failure before 2 months. ECG reading shows mitral valve stenosis with left atrial dilatation. A thrombus is present in the left atrium. One month later, he experiences flank pain on the left side and irritation and blood when urinating. An elevated serum AST was shown in the lab test report. Even after proper life-saving measures he died. A photograph of a section of the kidney obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following patterns of tissue necrosis is most likely to be present in this man?

A 78 year old presents to the emergency department due to crushing chest pain. Medical history include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. After 7 days he is pronounced dead.The microscopic appearance of myocardium section during autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following mediator produce this appearance?

A 5-year-old girl comes to the office due to an earache for 3 years. Each time on examination, the pain has been accompanied by a red, bulging tympanic membrane, sometimes with a small amount of yellowish exudate. Otoscopy shows a small perforation in the right tympanic membrane and a pearly mass behind the membrane. Conductive hearing loss is noted in the right ear. The girl responds to antibiotic therapy. The likely complications of these events are?

A 45-year-old man came into the emergency department with complaints of severe fatigue lasting over the past few months. He also mentions having swelling that started in the ankles. He also complains of his urine being foamy and dark. He decided to come in now due to the emergence of a rash. Cbc shows a severe increase in microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. His blood results were also positive for antinuclear antibodies and showed markedly raised esr. Upon physical examination, he was noted to be hypertensive with a rash noted over the malar bones and nasal bridge. Further histopathologic testing led to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis. An electron microscopy finding shows electron-dense deposits in mesangial, intramembranous, subendothelial, and subepithelial areas. There is a predominance in deposition noted in the subepithelial regions. There was severe mesangiocapillary proliferation with subendothelial immune deposits seen. Diffuse thickening of capillary walls is seen. Light microscopy demonstrates a “wire-loop” lesion. Which of the following morphological classification of lupus nephritis is likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:

questions.text: When innate immunity is to be studied, cells that participate in innate immunity are capable of recognizing certain microbial components that are shared among related microbes and are often essential for infectivity. Collectively, these cellular receptors are often called pattern recognition receptors. The best known among the pattern recognition receptors are the Toll-like receptors. Where are these receptors present in a cell?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ LEARNING OBJECTIVE:

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency room with complaints of headaches. He claims the pain increases progressively. A prompt CT scan of the head was done and revealed irregularly shaped hypodense lesions with a peripheral ringlike zone of contrast enhancement and a penumbra of cerebral edema. A subsequent MRI of the brain with contrast reveals an irregular mass lesion with peripheral contrast enhancement and central hyperenhancement. A biopsy of the tumor was taken. Histopathology revealed highly malignant astrocytic tumor cells surrounding areas of necrosis. Which of the following geneticmanifestations is seen in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arm 10q

options.label: D
options.text: loss of NF2 gene on chromosome 22q

questions.correct_answer: C. loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arm 10q
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented to the emergency room with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain radiating to the flank. He mentions he has not been able to urinate in the past 36 hours. He also claims to have pelvic distention. He has a previous history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Upon physical examination, a palpable distended bladder is noted along with palpable kidneys. Rectal examination was done and revealed a reduced anal tone with prostatic enlargement. Cbc was normal, serum chemistry studies revealed elevated BUN and creatinine levels. Renal ultrasound confirmed the presence of urinary tract obstruction and dilation of the urinary collecting system of the kidneys. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of periodic substernal chest pain. The pain radiates down the left arm and goes away when he takes a break. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg, and pulse is 85/min with irregular beats. Which of the following is most likely to explain the pathogenetic mechanism of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Ulcerated atherosclerotic plaque with partially obstructive thrombus

options.label: B
options.text: Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus

options.label: C
options.text: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus

options.label: D
options.text: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus

questions.correct_answer: D. Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus

questions.text: A 68-year-old man undergoes cardiac catheterization and stent placement for severe myocardial infarction. He does well until day 5 of hospitalization, then begins to complain of severe shortness of breath and chest pain. Physical examination reveals heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure is 65/40 mmHg and respiratory rate is 12 /min. He is clearly in distress and shows distant heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure. Which of the following complication is causing these symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: A. Rupture of ventricular free wall

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is having abdominal pain after 3 episodes of urinary tract infection during the past year. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows 2+ hematuria, 1+ proteinuria, hypercalciuria, and no glucose or ketones. An abdominal contrast CT scan is shown below. Her condition improves after increasing daily intake of fluids. Which renal cystic diseases are most likely associated with these findings?

A 3-year-old boy has a fever, abdominal pain, and three episodes of hematuria. On palpation, there is a tender abdominal mass on the right side extending across the midline. His cousin at a younger age also had a similar abdominal mass. An abdominal CT scan shows a large solid mass in the right kidney. A right-sided nephrectomy is performed and histopathology is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A Caucasian diabetic male presents to the nephrologist with flank pain. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a large mass on the left kidney. He began a high-intensity interval training program with his friend 3 days ago in an attempt to lose weight after being sedentary and stuck indoors for most of the summer. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the left lateral sternal border without edema or erythema over the area. There is no tenderness elsewhere or palpable crepitus. questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Differential Diagnosis
  • ↳ The differential diagnosis for costochondritis is rather long. Some of the diagnoses included are associated with major morbidity and mortality.
  • ↳ Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) This diagnosis should be considered in any patient presenting with chest pain. If you feel the patient's history and physical are concerning for ACS, consider an ECG and troponin level to assist in ruling out ACS. The patient should also be on continuous cardiac monitoring while in the emergency department.
  • ↳ Pneumothorax Consider the patient population at risk for spontaneous pneumothorax. A chest x-ray and/or point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) can be used to assist in evaluating the possibility of pneumothorax.
  • ↳ Pneumonia If the patient is complaining of a productive cough and/or fever or is at high risk for pneumonia, consider this on your differential diagnosis. Pneumonia can cause chest pain in addition to the other symptoms we associate with the diagnosis. A chest x-ray, complete blood count (CBC), and a basic metabolic panel (BMP) can be helpful when considering this as a differential diagnosis. Vital signs are also important when considering this diagnosis.
  • ↳ Aortic Dissection This is a medical and possibly a surgical emergency. Consider a CTA to evaluate for aortic dissection if this is a concern based on the patient's history and physical exam.
  • ↳ Pulmonary Embolism Ask about pulmonary embolism (PE) risk factors, such as malignancy, recent travel, recent surgery, personal history of PE or deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and symptoms, such as shortness of breath. Tachycardia can also be a sign of PE. Consider using a clinical decision rule, such as PERC and Well's criteria when considering PE. A D-dimer and/or CTA can be helpful when evaluating for a PE if this is on your differential diagnosis. There may also be nonspecific ECG and POCUS changes seen.
  • ↳ Esophageal Perforation The healthcare professional must have a high clinical suspicion for this diagnosis, and it is often due to an iatrogenic cause, such as a recent endoscopy. This patient's pain should be severe and unrelenting, and typically, they present in shock with abnormal vital signs.
  • ↳ INCORRECT OPTIONS:
  • ↳ OPTION A Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) might be indicated in patients with suspected costochondritis if there are accompanying manifestations that suggest an underlying inflammatory or rheumatologic condition (e.g., morning stiffness, arthralgia, myalgias, chest wall swelling), which this patient does not have.
  • ↳ OPTION B Chest x-ray is indicated in patients with acute chest pain and features that suggest a rib fracture(e.g., history of trauma, localized chest wall tenderness), a pulmonary cause of chest pain(e.g., cough, abnormal respiratory findings on auscultation), or heart failure(e.g., crackles on auscultation, peripheral edema, history of heart failure or other cardiac condition). In this young, otherwise healthy patient with suspected costochondritis, a chest x-ray is not indicated.
  • ↳ OPTION D Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and/or triamcinolone can be used to treat refractory cases of costochondritis. However, these treatments are not appropriate first-line therapies for this condition.
  • ↳ OPTION E Consider a CTA to evaluate for aortic dissection if this is a concern based on the patient's history and physical exam but in this case, history is suggestive of Costochondritis
  • ↳ EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE Acute-onset chest pain that is reproducible with palpation along the costochondral junction in a young patient who recently began a workout program is highly suggestive of costochondritis. For young patients in whom a diagnosis of costochondritis is highly suspected, supportive care (e.g., rest, ice, and analgesia) without further evaluation is appropriate if cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and there are no identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease(CVD).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the OPD with complaints of blurry vision, headache, and multiple episodes of nosebleeds over the last few weeks. During this time, she has also been itching a lot, especially after getting ready for work in the mornings. She has had an 8-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue during the past 6 months. Her pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg and RR = 16/min. Physical examination shows no lesions or evidence of trauma in the nasal cavity. Her face, palms, nail beds, oral mucosa, and conjunctiva appear red. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is19 g/dL, hematocrit is 58%, platelets are 450,000/μL, and erythropoietin level is below normal. A peripheral blood smear shows RBC precursor cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ These criteria should only be applied for diagnosis after secondary causes of polycythemia have been ruled out.
  • ↳ Treatment / Management
  • ↳ There is no cure for polycythemia vera; goals of treatment are aimed at symptom relief and reducing the risk of disease complications, including thrombosis, bleeding, and hematologic transformation.
  • ↳ 1. Patients under the age of 60 without a history of thrombotic events are considered low risk and treatment recommendations include:
  • ↳ Phlebotomy, target hematocrit to less than 45% Daily low-dose aspirin, if no contraindications Treat aspirin refractory symptoms Optimizing cardiovascular (CV) health such as weight loss, exercise, tobacco cessation, blood pressure control.
  • ↳ Phlebotomy, target hematocrit to less than 45%
  • ↳ Daily low-dose aspirin, if no contraindications
  • ↳ Treat aspirin refractory symptoms
  • ↳ Optimizing cardiovascular (CV) health such as weight loss, exercise, tobacco cessation, blood pressure control.
  • ↳ 2. Patients 60 years of age or older and/or have a history of thrombosis are considered high risk, and recommendations are the same as for low-risk patients with the addition of cytoreductive therapy (hydroxyurea, interferon, busulfan) and treating disease-specific complications
  • ↳ OTHER OPTIONS
  • ↳ OPTION A Renal cell carcinoma(RCC) can cause paraneoplastic syndrome, in which increased EPO production results in an inappropriate absolute polycythemia. Individuals with RCC may present with findings similar to those seen in this patient, including elevated RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), elevated platelet count, weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome, pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, and plethora. However, this patient presents with low EPO levels, making paraneoplastic syndrome unlikely. Moreover, she lacks other typical features of RCC, including hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass.
  • ↳ OPTION B An EPO receptor mutation is a typical finding in individuals with primary familial and congenital polycythemia(PFCP). PFCP is a rare disorder that may manifest with findings similar to those seen in polycythemia vera, including highly elevated RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), low EPO levels, plethora, fatigue, headache, hypertension, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, a patient with PFCP would typically have a normal-sized spleen, earlier onset of symptoms, and a family history positive for this condition. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of PFCP, such as a normal platelet count, which indicates that other hematopoietic cell lines are not involved (isolated erythrocytosis).
  • ↳ OPTION C Stress erythrocytosis(Gaisbock syndrome) is a form of secondary erythrocytosis characterized by an increase in RBC mass due to a decrease in plasma volume (relative polycythemia). The condition can manifest with typical findings of polycythemia vera, including a (relative) increase of RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), hypertension, plethora, neurological symptoms, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, this condition typically occurs in obese middle-aged men receiving diuretic treatment, which is not the case for this patient. Moreover, stress erythrocytosis would not explain this patient's splenomegaly, elevated platelet count, and low EPO levels.
  • ↳ OPTION E PAX5 mutations occur frequently in adult B-cell progenitoracute lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • ↳ EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE A mutation in the Janus kinase 2(JAK2)gene is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of polycythemia vera(PV) and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia(ET) and primary myelofibrosis(PMF).

The baby was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and is vaccinated to date. On examination, His height has reached a plateau over the past eight weeks and now rests on the 9th centile for his age. He is alert and happy, although he rubs his legs vigorously when undressed. He has generally dry skin, with widespread low-grade erythema and raised, poorly defined patches of active eczema and there are widespread excoriations and no clinical evidence of impetiginization. He has low-grade generalized lymphadenopathy. The rest of his examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

He has had no recent illnesses but has had intermittent pain in his legs during his soccer games for the past 3 months. The patient had no trauma preceding the onset of leg pain, has no numbness or tingling, and is able to walk without a limp. He was born at 38 weeks gestation via a spontaneous vaginal delivery with no complications. The patient has met all developmental milestones, and all of his immunizations are up to date. His father was recently diagnosed with hypertension at age 55, but there is no other significant family history. Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 135/88 n1m Hg in the right upper extremity, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and pulse oximetry is 98°/o on room air. Weight and height are at the 25th and 50th percentiles, respectively, for age. Physical examination shows a well-appearing boy who has no dysmorphic features and who smiles and fully cooperates. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart rate and rhythm are normal. A 2/6 continuous murmur is heard over the left interscapular area. No swelling, erythema, or tenderness is present in the lower extremities. Further evaluation would most likely show which of the following findings?

A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain and light-headedness for the past hour. He was clearing away debris in his backyard when he suddenly felt substernal chest pressure accompanied by cold sweats. The pain has been constant, radiates to the left jaw, and is not relieved by rest or the nitro-glycerine spray he received in the ambulance. The patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension. He smokes occasionally, especially on weekends, but does not use alcohol. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 60. On examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. The extremities are cold. Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg, the pulse is 34/min, and respirations are 16/min. Oxygen saturation is 94°/o on 4 U/min nasal cannula oxygen. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at both lung bases. There are no heart murmurs. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a 3-mm ST-segment elevation in leads II, Ill, and AFV. Which of the following is most appropriate as part of initial management for this patient?

A 4-week-old male infant with Down's syndrome is brought by his parents to your office due to feeding difficulties. According to the mother, the infant becomes short of breath and his face turns blue during feeding, and when he cries. On chest auscultation, there is a harsh holosystolic murmur heard best over the lower left sternal border. There are no rates of wheezing over the lung fields.Which of the following is the most useful test for diagnostic evaluation?

A 59-year-old man comes to the office due to cough and mild dyspnea His symptoms began 10 days ago with nasal congestion and a sore throat, which improved spontaneously after a few days. However, the cough, productive of white sputum, has persisted. He has also had an episode of blood-streaked sputum. The patient has a history of hypertension and stable coronary artery disease. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack-year history The patient is a car salesman and has not traveled recently Temperature is 36.7 C (98 1 F}, his blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg, and his respirations are 18/min. Lung examination shows scattered wheezes bilaterally. Chest x-ray demonstrates no parenchymal infiltrate or consolidation, but a 2-cm peripherally located nodule is present in the left lower lobe. No prior chest imaging is available. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening asthma symptoms for 2-3 days She has shortness of breath, wheezing, and productive cough The patient describes thick sputum that was blood-tinged yesterday. She was diagnosed with asthma 12 years ago but says that it had not been this bad until last year For the past year the patient has had 2 hospitalizations for asthma exacerbations but has never been intubated. She completed a course of oral prednisone and azithromycin 2 months ago Current medications include a daily fluticasone inhaler and as-needed albuterol inhaler The patient reports no decrease in appetite or \¥eight loss and has not traveled outside of her home state of New Jersey in the past 2 years She works as a school teacher and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs The patient has no second-hand tobacco exposure and no known allergies. Her grandmother also has asthma. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 123/80 mm Hg, the pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry shows 95o/o on room air Pulmonary examination reveals scattered wheezes. Heart sounds are normal. clubbing, peripheral edema, or skin rashes. Complete blood count shows the following: Item 1 of 2 Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL Platelets 200,000/mm3 Leucocytes 11 ,500/mm3 Neutrophils 65% Lymphocytes 22% Eosinophils 10% Monocytes 3% Chest x-ray reveals patchy bilateral upper lobe infiltrates and prominent bronchial markings. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosing the cause of this patient's worsening symptoms?

options.label: B
options.text: Asking the patient to demonstrate proper inhaler technique

questions.correct_answer: A. Allergy skin testing for Aspergillus

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6 months history of fatigue and worsening pruritus which is accompanied by yellowing of the skin. She has a past medical history of hypertension for which she is on amlodipine and vitamin supplements. On physical examination, she is noted to have hyperpigmented skin with many scratch excoriations. Her abdomen is soft and non-distended with moderate hepatomegaly. She denies smoking or drinking. A detailed lab examination revealed an increase in alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, and total cholesterol levels. She has also become positive for antimitochondrial antibodies and antinuclear antibodies. Abdominal ultrasound shows an enlarged liver. Which of the following disease is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune disease that presents with jaundice and pruritus in middle-aged women. It causes elevated alkaline phosphatase levels along with an increase in antimitochondrial antibodies and antinuclear antibodies titers.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and abdominal pain which is accompanied by fatigue and weakness. He appears cachectic and thin and has yellow-tinged skin. His vitals are stable except for T-38.4 C. His past medical history is unremarkable. He is a smoker and alcoholic. On examination, he had right upper quadrant tenderness, hepatosplenomegaly, and a palpable fluid wave. A detailed lab investigation was done which revealed the following : Alkaline phosphatase : 180 U/L, aspartate am inotransferase : 320 U/L ,alanine aminotransferase: 140 U/L ,Total bilirubin : 3.8 mg/dL and Direct bilirubin : 1.2 mg/dL. which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man presented to the emergency department with the chief complaint of generalized weakness, abdominal pain, nausea, and palpitations. He has a past medical history of hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease for which he is on dialysis for the past 1yr. He admits that he is not compliant with his medications. He is a smoker and an occasional drinker. On further questioning, he told that he missed two of his dialysis appointments. Upon physical examination he has decreased motor strength in both his upper and lower extremities, intact cranial nerves, and decreased bowel sounds. Lab investigations are ordered and ECG was taken. Which of the following will most likely be found on electrocardiography?

options.label: A
options.text: ST-segment elevation in leads lead I ,II ,III and IV

options.label: B
options.text: Progressive PR prolongation, followed by a 'drop' in QRS

options.label: C
options.text: inverted T wave in lead III, S wave in lead I and Q wave in lead III

options.label: D
options.text: Shortened QT interval and hyper acute T-waves

questions.correct_answer: D. Shortened QT interval and hyper acute T-waves

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to you for a routine physical examination. He says that he is experiencing extreme weakness, weight loss, frequent urination, decrease in appetite, and also has not had a bowel movement in the past 5 days. He feels totally uncomfortable. On examination, he complains of abdominal pain. His temperature is (37.4°C), blood pressure is 130/88 mmHg, the pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 18/min. During the course of the examination, you also noted that he is having difficulty remembering. His cranial nerve exam is unremarkable and his gait is stable. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following tests is most likely to be done in the next step?

A 40-Year-old pregnant woman comes to the office for a prenatal visit at 20 weeks gestation. The fetal sex chromosomes are XX but the transabdominal ultrasound shows male external genitalia. If High BP, decreased potassium, decreased cortisol are findings likely to be seen in the infant after birth. what will be your probable diagnosis?

David, a 22 year old young man, who works as a mechanic and struggling with financial issues. He had recently moved to the southern part of states. One day he visited the primary care hospital with the difficulty of itching eyes. Also mentioned that after he moved, he experienced watering and itching of eyes, that made him unable to focus and not give proper attention to his work. He has previous medical history of asthma and his ongoing medications contain fluticasone, albuterol, whey protein supplements and fish oil. During his physical examination, his blood pressure is 102/67 mmHg , respiratory rate 16/min, pulse 62/min and oxygen saturation on room air is 98.5%. During his eye examination , there is bilateral finding noticed as illustrated in the image given below. While remaining physical and cardiopulmonary examination is found to be normal. What is the most probable diagnosis in this clinical scenario?

You are posted as an Internal med resident and a 36-year-old woman presents to you with a chief complaint of joint pain in her hands. She stated that the pain is worse in the morning but is present throughout the day which is not relieved by ibuprofen. She recently noted that her right 5th finger began to swell and is painful. She also complains of changes in her nails, which have become brittle in recent times. She has a history of smoking and drinking. Her past medical history is unremarkable except for her lower back pain which is well controlled by NSAIDs. Her temperature is 37.2°C, pressure is 130/80 mmHg, the pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 17/min. On examination, the distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand are tender to palpation. The Achilles tendons are tender bilaterally. Additionally, a rash on the right elbow with red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales is identified. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old woman comes to your clinic complaining of general body malaise and a facial rash which appeared two weeks ago when she participated in a welfare marathon. She used some topicals, but no improvement is seen. She denies pain or pruritus and denies any changes in lotions or soaps. The patient has a history of diabetes and hypertension. she was recently prescribed a new medication by her primary care physician. The patient does not have any habit of smoking or drinking. She works as a clerk in a college. The patient’s temperature is 37.1°C, blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, the pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 17/min. On physical exam, an oral ulcer, and mild joint stiffness and swelling of the patient’s hands and knees are noted. You feel that her current symptoms are drug-related. Which of the following could be the medication causing her symptoms?

20-year-old swimmer who has been in excellent health and takes no chronic medications, for new-onset severe fatigue and left upper abdominal pain. She was treated 2 days ago in hospital for presumed typhoid with cefotaxime. She also had past h/o typhoid in 2 yrs back. On physical examination her heart rate of 120 bpm and a palpable spleen. Stool is negative for heme. Lab investigations shows hemoglobin of 5 g/dL with normal TLC and platelets. Peripheral blood smear reveals an excess of spherocytes. All of the following can cause similar type of this condition except:
Which of the following is the most common microorganism known to cause tropical pyomyositis?

questions.text: A pregnant female complains of sudden onset of multiple generalized vesiculobullous lesions almost all over the body associated with pain and mild fever. She has B/L knee joint pain without any redness or swelling of joints. On examination the lesions are found to have pustular tips with surrounding red hue (see the following picture). questions.explanation:
REM sleep has -

questions.text: A 4 year old boy was brought to your clinic for wetting his pants in day time. The parents claim that, he has been like this from the beginning. Upon a examining his genital system, the urethral opening was seen more proximal and ventral when comparing to a normal person. Among which of the following, circumcision is contraindicated?

A 78 year old woman is brought to the emergency department due to 2 weeks of progressive confusion, however, for the past week, she has been more confused and sleeping most of the time. Her daughter tells that she fell in washroom few weeks ago . She has also developed a mild headache. The patient has had no fever, vomiting, or urinary symptoms. Her other medical problems include hypertension and osteoarthritis. Blood pressure is 140 /76 mm Hg and pulse is 86 /min and regular. She is somnolent but arousable. The patient gives several inaccurate answers but is able to follow simple instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 3/5 on the left. Plantar reflex is upgoing on the left. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

0/5

No muscle movement

1/5

Visible muscle movement, but no movement at the joint

2/5

Movement at the joint, but not against gravity

3/5

Movement against gravity, but not against gravity

4/5

Movement against resistance, but less than normal

5/5

Normal Strength

questions.text: A 42-year-old garbage collector came in for a consultation. The main complaints of the patient is an ulcerating, blue pigmented nodule around 1.5 cm in diameter over the left lateral surface to his nose. An excision biopsy was done, and it revealed ovoid cells in nose with a single ‘pallisading’ layer. The patient was refferred to a plastic surgeon for grafting. Which of the following grafts should be used?

In a motor vehicle accident, a 23 year old male patient sustained an open bone fracture. After the appropriate treatment, he was sent home. Few weeks later, the patient developed erythema and supraregional vesiculation at the injured site along with fever and chills. (+) serosanguineous noted. Later the patient came to consultation with this presentation (image below). Which of the following is the working diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Necrotising fasciitis is a surgical emergency with polymicrobial synergistic infection which can rapidly progress to septic shock. Urgent resuscitation along with antibiotics and surgical debridement should be done.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with the mass of 3 cm behind his left ear. The biopsy report of the mass is positive for staining of cytokeratins 1 and 10. The nearest lymphnodes were palpable and of around 2cm in diameter on the same side as of the lesion. (-) distant metastasis noted. What is the TNM classification of the tumor ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a malignant tumour of keratinising cells of the epidermis or its appendages. It arises from the stratum basalis of the epidermis and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10.Squamous cell carcinoma can be graded histologically according to Border’s grading, which describes the proportion of dedifferentiated cells in the tumor. In TNM classification T denotes the tumor size, N denotes the size of the node involved, M indicates metastasis.

Size

Nodes

Mets

TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed

Nx Nodal involvement cannot be assessed

M0No metastatic disease

T0No evidence of primary tumor

N0 No regional nodes

M1 Metastatic disease present

Tis In situ (confined to full thickness epidermal) disease

N1 Spread to ipsilateral nearby node that is < 3cm diameter

 

T1Primary < 2cm

N2a Spread to ipsilateral nearby node that is 3-6cm diameter

 

T2Primary > 2cm

N2b Spread to >1 ipsilateral nearby nodes,but none > 6cm diameter

 

T3Primary invasion of a facial bone

N2c Spread to contralateral node(s), but none are > 6cm diameter

 

T4Invasion of muscle, base of skull or other bones

N3Spread to any node > 6cm diameter

questions.text: A 62 -year-old man comes to the emergency department with substernal chest pain, severe shortness of breath, and diaphoresis that began suddenly 50 minutes ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and was not relieved with antacids . The patient has vomited twice since the pain started. Electrocardiogram shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. His medical problems include peptic ulcer disease, for which he takes omeprazole. Blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. Sublingual nitroglycerin and aspirin are administered and within minutes the patient reports resolution of pain. Which of the following most likely accounts for the improvement in his symptoms?

A 62 -year-old man comes to the emergency department with substernal chest pain, severe shortness of breath, and diaphoresis that began suddenly 50 minutes ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and does not remit with sublingual nitroglycerin The patient has vomited twice since the pain started. Electrocardiogram shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. On physical examination, the patient's temperature is 36.9 C , blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 4 L/min oxygen by nasal canula. Cardiac examination shows an S3. Lung examination shows basilar crackles that extend halfway up the lung fields bilaterally. He is given 325 mg of aspirin, 600 mg of clopidogrel, and 80 mg of atorvastatin. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

A 72-year-old man undergoes coronary artery bypass graft for severe coronary artery disease. He is extubated on the second postoperative day. On the third postoperative day he complains of dyspnea and worsening retrosternal pain despite continuous analgesia with morphine. His temperature is 38.6° C , blood pressure is 112/52 mm Hg, pulse is 125/min and irregularly irregular and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows normal heart sounds. A small amount of cloudy fluid is present in the sternal wound drain. His ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. An x-ray film of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. Laboratory studies show Hemoglobin 8.9 mg/L WBC Count 16,300/mm3 Which of the following will this patient most likely require?
questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical debridement and antibiotic therapy

questions.text: One the leading South Indian actress who underwent a rib resection recently, got involved in a road traffic accident and had a strong impact onto her lower back. Upon presenting to the emergency room, she was well, complained of lower back pain only. She left the hospital against medical advice. After 24 hours, she developed a bluish discoloration over her flank area on the same side of the pain, she had earlier. It is an abdominal emergency. Among which of the following, this discoloration is denoted as ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Grey turner sign- skin discoloration of the flanks due to retroperitoneal hemorrhage in severe acute pancreatitis and leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is an abdominal emergency.

questions.text: A 62 year old female patient experienced intermittent abdominal fullness with gradual aggravation for 2 months. She also had loss of appetite. She visited a local clinic, where upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a duodenal ulcer. She was referred to other big facility, suspecting for progressive ileus. She presented with vomiting and absence of passage of flatus and feces for three days. The patient had no history of systemic diseases and had not undergone any surgery. Abdominal examination reveled distension and mild epigastric tenderness. No palpable lump noted. A CT was done (given below). Which among the following will be the working diagnosis ?

A twenty year old male patient was diagnosed with acute appendicitis and underwent an open appendectomy via Rockey-Davis incision. After few months, the patient had a slow progressively growing erythematous lump at the incisional site. He complains of pain while doing valsalva maneuver. Later the patient developed, vomiting and constipation along with fever. Which of the following diagnostic methods, you will use to support your diagnosis ?

A young weight lifting aspirant was making his way through the higher leagues in weight lifting contest, through his vigorous training sessions. He is eyeing for the gold medal in the upcoming Olympics. He underwent constant training to achieve his goal. Initially he had symptoms of regurgitation and heart burn occasionally. But he ignored them and still pursued his training sessions. During a training session, he increased the weights, where after lifting, he felt a severe chest pain radiating to the back. After few minutes he developed dyspnea, that is when he was brought to the emergency bay. ECG was normal. Chest X-ray reveal air in the mediastinum. At this time, what will be the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Perforation of the oesophagus is usually iatrogenic (at therapeutic endoscopy) or due to ‘barotrauma’ (spontaneous perforation). Barotrauma has also been described in relation to other pressure events when the patient strains against a closed glottis (e.g. defecation, labour, weight-lifting). The diagnosis can usually be suspected from history and associated clinical features. A chest radiograph is often confirmatory with air in the mediastinum, pleura or peritoneum.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male driver is brought to the ER after a motor vehicle accident in a comatose state. At accident spot, his blood pressure is 50/30 mm Hg and heart rate is 150/min. On examination, chest is clear on auscultation. A large bruise is seen is seen on abdominal wall. Abdomen is mildly distended. Bowel sounds are decreased. Neck veins are collapsed .After infusion of two liters of intravenous fluids, his blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. FAST shows blood in the peritoneal cavity but no obvious solid organ injury. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 58 -year-old man undergoes a partial hepatectomy . The surgery is complicated by excessive bleeding . The patient receives packed red blood cell transfusion during the surgery as well as intravenous normal saline. He is transferred to the surgical intensive care unit for close monitoring and is successfuly extubated. Twelve hours later, his oxygen saturation started decreasing . The patient has received multiple doses of morphine for pain control since the surgery. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 28/min. The patient's pulse oximetry shows 88% on 4 L nasal cannula oxygen. Examination reveals bilateral basal crackles. The abdomen is mildly distended and tender, and bowel sounds are decreased. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity. Pulmonary artery catheter readings show a cardiac index of 2 L/min/m2 (normal: 2.8-4.2) and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 20 mm Hg (normal: 6-15). Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's current condition?

A 73 -year-old man having some exertional shortness of breath for the past few months , is brought to the emergency department after he passed out during an early morning jog. The patient felt lightheaded while jogging and sat down on the curb to prevent a fall. He wnot confused after the episode and did not have bowel or bladder incontinence. The patient has hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide but is healthy otherwise. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and occasionally drinks wine. His blood pressure 142/90 mm Hg, pulse 30/min, and respirations are 16/min. Carotid pulse is delayed. S2 is diminished and S4 is present. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heared in the right second intercostal space. On neurological examinatin, no focal findings and there are no head traumal signs. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy.Cardiac enzymes are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

A 48 -year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident . The patient is awake and oriented but in distress due to pain in the right lower extremity and groin. Blood pressure is 122/86 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 16/min. Abrasions and bruises are observed over the posterior and left lateral chest wall. Chest auscultation reveals clear lung fields and no cardiac murmurs. The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Bruising is visible over the right groin and thigh . Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are palpable. Bedside ultrasound examination reveals no pericardial or free abdominal fluid. Two large-bore intravenous catheters and a Foley catheter are placed. Thirty minutes after arrival, the patient reports difficulty breathing and lightheadedness. Doctor on duty measues blood pressure and it is now 80/50 mm Hg and heart rate is 120/min and regular. Immediate examination shows erythematous rash and wheals over the chest and abdomen. The patient is a hospital house keeper in the same hospital. Which of these is cause of this patient's hemodynamic deterioration?

A 24-year-old presents to the antenatal clinic with a history of amenorrhea of 2 months and a positive pregnancy test. She is now married for 1 year and this is her first pregnancy, she has had multiple sexual partners prior to marriage and has never used contraception. On routine antenatal testing, she is found to be HIV positive. She is currently asymptomatic and wishes to continue the pregnancy. Reports for HIV viral load and CD4 counts are awaited. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Start ART and advice follow up

options.label: C
options.text: Start ART if HIV viral loads >1000 copies/mL

questions.correct_answer: B. Start ART and advice follow up

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravida has conceived after ovulation induction and presents for routine antenatal evaluation. She has no complaints at present and she is 12 weeks gestation from her date of last menstrual period. Her doctor advises her for an aneuploidy screening test, considering her advanced age of conception. She has no past or family history of aneuploidies. Which of the following is the most appropriate test(s) to be prescribed at this stage?

options.label: B
options.text: Dual marker + ultrasound for nuchal translucency

options.label: C
options.text: Quadruple marker + ultrasound for nasal bone

questions.correct_answer: B. Dual marker + ultrasound for nuchal translucency

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the physician preconceptionally for advice. She is a known epileptic on anticonvulsant therapy with phenytoin for 10 years. She has been well controlled on therapy and her last seizure was 8 years ago. She and her partner have been using contraceptive pills for the past two years but have now stopped using them. She has no other significant medical history and has regular menses. Examinations show BP 122/78 mmHg, PR 105/min, the systemic and abdominal examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate pre conceptional counseling for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Should not attempt a pregnancy and opt for adoption or surrogacy instead as epilepsy causes fetal malformations

options.label: B
options.text: Increase the dose of phenytoin due to high risk of seizures in pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Stop anticonvulsant therapy and plan a pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Folate supplementation and consider switching to levetiracitam

questions.correct_answer: D. Folate supplementation and consider switching to levetiracitam

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 woman presents with painful and engorged right breast for 5 days. She delivered a healthy male newborn 2 weeks ago by cesarean section. The pain stays through most of the day and subsides minimally and transiently with analgesics. She has no past history of any serious illness. On examination, PR is 108/min BP is 122/76 mmHg, temp is 100.4’F, the right breast is enlarged, tender, and appears warmer than surrounding skin and the left breast. the nipple of the right breast shows cracks and is everted. The left breast, areola, and nipple appear healthy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old woman presents to the physician for routine postpartum evaluation. She had an LSCS 1 week back done for prolonged leaking with nonprogress of labor. She had postpartum hemorrhage which was managed by oxytocin and methyl ergometrine. She presently has some constipation which is relieved with lactulose syrup. She has mild lower abdominal pain which increases with suckling by the baby. There is no fever. She is breastfeeding her newborn well. She is still having vaginal bleeding and is soaking 2 to 3 pads every day. Examination shows PR of 78/min, BP of 122/76 mmHg, abdominal examination shows an incision with interrupted sutures, which are now cut, there is also a firm globular mobile, non-tender pelvic mass measuring 14 weeks size. Vaginal examination shows bleeding not associated with foul smell and episiotomy is healthy. Her breasts are enlarged and show milk discharge bilaterally. CBC shows Hb 11.2 gm%, TLC 10,500/cumm, platelets 1.7 lakh/cumm. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

A 26-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea for 4 months. She is presently nursing her 4-month-old baby which was delivered by a cesarean section done for breech presentation and pre-eclampsia at full-term pregnancy. There was some postpartum hemorrhage which was managed conservatively and did not require a blood transfusion. She is exclusively breastfeeding since then, around 6-8 times in the day and 2 feeds at night. Her only medication is a calcium supplement. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Examination reveals stable vitals and unremarkable organ systems, breasts are enlarged and lactating and no mass is felt per abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her amenorrhea?

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of GnRH secretion due to pituitary apoplexy

questions.correct_answer: A. Prolactin induced inhibition of GnRH

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at term with labor pains. Her pains started 8 hours back and have been slowly increasing in duration and intensity and each pain is associated with tightening of the abdomen. Her antenatal records show no high-risk factor and an ultrasound a week ago shows a single live fetus corresponding to 38 weeks gestation, fundal placenta, adequate liquor, and cephalic presentation. On examination uterine contractions are felt 3 in every 10 minutes, lasting 40-50 seconds, fetal heart rate is good. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is fully dilated and the fetal head is felt at 0 stations. On the fetal head, anterior fontanelle and supra-orbital ridge are felt. Membranes are present and the pelvis appears average, gynaecoid. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

A 24-year-old primigravida presents at 39 weeks of pregnancy for antenatal evaluation. She is a diabetic on insulin, is hypothyroid, taking thyroxine supplementation, and is short-statured. Her sugars presently are uncontrolled and so she is admitted for induction of labor, as the bishops are favorable and pelvis appears adequate. She goes into labor after a single dose of misoprostol and is thereafter augmented with oxytocin. Labour progresses smoothly till the second stage with adequate contractions, however, there is the arrest of descent of fetal head in the second stage. An emergency LSCS is performed and a live male baby weighing 4200 gms is delivered. Which of the following in the patient’s history is a risk factor for such presentation?

A 29-year-old primigravida presents at 38 weeks + 4 days for routine evaluation. All her antenatal records so far are normal and she is taking her daily iron and calcium supplements regularly. On examination, however, her BP is 150/100 mmHg and the obstetrician plans to terminate the pregnancy. Fetal heart tracing is reactive. A vaginal examination reveals no cervical dilatation, posterior cervix with a medium consistency, a cervical length of 3cm, and vertex at a station of -3. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
