questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician's office by her mother due to complaints of indigestion and diffuse lower abdominal pain for the past 4 months. She feels tired and nauseated most of the time but has not been vomiting. The pain is limited to the lower abdomen and does not increase or decrease with activity. She has normal bladder and bowel habits with a slight increase in the frequency of urination, There has been no weight loss over the period. She consumes a healthy and balanced diet mainly composed of fruits vegetables and meat. She plays for her volleyball team from school and is good at athletics. She has not yet had her first menstrual period. Her father has a history of hypertension and diabetes controlled on medications. On examination she is 5’5’’ tall, weighs 120 lb, BP is 126/78 mmHg, PR 82/min. chest and CVS are unremarkable. Breasts are tanner stage 5 and are tender to touch. A mobile mass is felt in the lower abdomen with its not limit not reachable. Which of the following is the next most appropriate investigation in this patient?

A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic for her first visit at 7 weeks of pregnancy. She has no complaints of pain or spotting per vaginum. She occasionally has nausea but no vomiting. She is able to take her routine diet and is taking folic acid medication. Her ultrasound is suggestive of a gestational sac in the uterus, with a mean sac diameter measuring 30 mm with no yolk sac or fetal pole. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Very early pregnancy requiring follow up

questions.text: A 30 year old P1L1 presents to the physician with complains of amenorrhea since her delivery 10 months back and gradual decrease in her breast size. Her menstrual cycles were regular prior to pregnancy. Her pregnancy was spontaneously conceived with a normal antenatal course and vaginal delivery, however she had severe postpartum bleeding which was managed with drugs and multiple blood transfusions. Postpartum, she used formula feed for her baby as the milk never came in. She never resumed her periods and is now also noticing a diminishing breast size. Her urine pregnancy test is negative and pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16 year old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as she has not attained menarche yet. She is not sexually active. Her vitals are stable, height is 150 cms and BMI is 24 kg/m2. Specific examination reveals breast development and presence of pubic and axillary hair, however her vagina appears blind. An ultrasound reveals absent uterus and cervix and a right ovarian simple cyst. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A couple with infertility of 2 years duration, presents to the infertility clinic for evaluation. The woman , 26 years of age, has a history of delayed cycles, coming every 35-45 days, lasting 4-5 days, with no dysmenorrhea. She has no history of thyroid disease. On examination, her BMI is 24 kg/m2, BP is 110/68 mmHg, systemic examination is unremarkable. An ultrasound does not show any significant pathology. A hysterosalpingography done shows bilateral patent tubes. Which of the following is the next best test for evaluation of this patient?

A 27 year old woman, P2L2, presents to her physician for contraceptive advice. Her cycles are regular with normal flow. She is a non smoker, vegetarian and has no significant past medical history. The doctor prescribes her a pack of combined oral contraceptive pills, the woman does not desire any future pregnancies and wishes to know whether the pills can be used for long term. Which of the following is a long term complication that she may have?

A 32 year old female presents to the infertility clinic for evaluation. She has been married for 4 years and has not used any contraception since but has still not been able to conceive. She has regular menstrual cycles lasting 4 days, occurring every 28-30 days with normal flow. However she complains of lower abdominal cramps starting 2 days prior to her periods and subsiding by the second or third day of her periods and also complains of pain during intercourse. Her husband is a non smoker non alcoholic with no coital dysfunction or significant medical history. On bimanual examination uterus appears normal in size with posterior forniceal tenderness. Her initial pelvic scan shows no significant pelvic pathology and hormonal profile is normal. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?

A 26 year old female presents to the infertility clinic for inability to conceive for the past 2 years. She is nulliparous, married for 3 years and has not been using contraception for the past two years. Her menstrual cycles are delayed, coming at intervals of 40-50 days, lasting 5 days with average flow and not associated with any dysmenorrhea. She has been taking treatment for acne since a year and has no other significant past history. Her husband is a non-smoker, healthy male of 28 years age, with no significant past history. On examination, her BMI is 30 kg/m2, BP is 120/70mmHg, chest, CVS , abdomen and pelvic examination are unremarkable. USG suggests B/L ovaries with multiple small cysts. Which of the following drugs is used in next line of management of this patient ?

A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with seizures. She reports that the patient has previously had seizures a few times per year since he was 12 months of age. His birth history shows, he was a term infant born to a 28 year old mother with no preexisting medical problems. Labor and delivery was notable for a tight nuchal cord. The infant was delivered vaginally. The infant had no respiratory distress and fed adequately overnight. Early in the morning on the second day of life, she has a 30 seconds seizure. He is taken to the nursery and oxygen is administered. An IV is started and a loading dose of phenobarbital is given. She is then transferred to the NICU. On physical exam, No dysmorphic features are evident. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart rate is regular without murmurs. Abdomen is with normal umbilicus, no masses, no hepatosplenomegaly and normal genitalia. Extremities are well perfused with good pulses. The patient’s past medical history is otherwise notable for intellectual disability. He rolled over at 14 months of age and walked at 24 months of age. The patient’s mother denies any family history of epilepsy or other neurologic diseases. The patient is in the 3rd percentile for height and the 15th percentile for weight. The patient has strabismus and an ataxic gait accompanied by flapping of the hands. He responds intermittently to questions with one-word answers. This patient is most likely to have which of the following genetic abnormalities?
questions.correct_answer: D. Paternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Angelman syndrome (AS) is characterized by severe developmental delay or intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, gait ataxia and/or tremulousness of the limbs, and a unique behavior with an inappropriate happy demeanor that includes frequent laughing, smiling, and excitability. Microcephaly and seizures are also common. A majority of affected patients also present with seizures.

questions.text: Lakshmi is a 2 year old child brought to the pediatricians office by her parents who noted her to be pale. Past medical History showed no fever, nausea, emesis, bone pain or other complaints. Her physical examination is significant for pallor, tachycardia, and a systolic ejection murmur, but there was no signs of organomegaly. A complete blood count (CBC) was ordered which showed the following results: hemoglobin of 4 g/dL, normal indices for age, a WBC count of 6.5/μL, and a platelet count of 750,000/μL. Her reticulocyte count is 0%. Coombs test was negative. Peripheral blood smear showed no blast forms and no fragments. Red blood cell (RBC) adenosine deaminase levels are normal. A bone marrow shows decreased erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis?
If one parent is normal and the other is a carrier and the child is also affected in an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder, what could be the possible reason for this?

Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a loss of function of specific genes on chromosome 15. In newborns, symptoms include weak muscles, poor feeding, and slow development. Beginning in childhood, those affected become constantly hungry, which often leads to obesity and type 2 diabetes. Mild to moderate intellectual impairment and behavioral problems. Which of the following hormones are raised in this syndrome?

A 1.5-year-old child was brought to the OPD by her mother after she began to notice that the child is not able to digest any of the dairy products she fed him with. She noticed that the symptoms usually begin from 30 minutes to two hours after eating or drinking foods that contain lactose. Common signs and symptoms include Diarrhea, vomiting. All are seen in lactose intolerance EXCEPT?

After the massive tsunami, lakhs of people were left homeless and had many injuries while saving themselves or others. After few days when the scenario was quite better than before, stranded people were moved to safer places and immediately sent to hospitals on the basis of triage. Mass vaccination for communicable diseases was carried out to provide herd immunity. Which vaccine given was not effective in providing herd immunity?
Areola and papilla forming secondary mound in adolescent girls is classified under which stage of sexual maturity rating (SMR)?
A three day-old term infant born at home, breast-fed exclusively, presented with lethargy, bulging fontanel, and bright red blood from rectum. What is the most likely etiology of his disease?

A 17 yrs old boy presented with sudden onset of severe throbbing pain in his right ear following an upper respiratory tract infection. He also gives a history of bloodstained discharge couple of hours later along with hearing impairment in the affected ear. Following is the otoscopy findings of the patient. Most likely diagnosis is:
Most common cause of Lower motor neuron facial palsy is

45 years old chronic smoker came to your clinic with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx. Laryngoscopy revealed the features depicted in the below image. Which of the following sites will be the most common site of distant metastasis?
Identify the procedure shown below & its application.

options.label: B
options.text: Indirect laryngoscopy, differentiate malignant from benign lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Laryngeal videostroboscopy, gives additional information about the vibratory pattern of the vocal fold mucosa

options.label: D
options.text: Vocobronchoscopy, identifying mobility of vocal cord

questions.correct_answer: C. Laryngeal videostroboscopy, gives additional information about the vibratory pattern of the vocal fold mucosa

questions.text: 10 years old boy came to your clinic with severe throat pain. On examination, you diagnosed it as Tonsillitis. You planned for a Tonsillectomy procedure and during that procedure, the patient developed bleeding intraoperatively. Which of the following is the source of bleeding in this scenario?

A 75 year old retired police officer came to your OPD with a history of odynophagia and dysphagia . When you examined him, you noticed that there is a unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall. Xray reveals the below-depicted image. The space involved in this condition is?

A patient developed bilateral nasal obstruction and fever with chills after septal surgery. On anterior rhinoscopy a smooth fluctuant swelling is noted on both sides of septum. What could be the diagnosis?
Which of the following is the sign for pink reflex through tympanic membrane seen in active otosclerosis?

A 12 year old boy is brought to the clinic due to eye redness and discharge. He had a sore throat for 7 days and right eye redness for 2 days.Yesterday his father used a moisture to open the his both crusted eyelids and then left eye also became red. The boy has no eye pain, visual changes or itching. No one in his family has similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.4 °C. Physical examination reveals mild infection and granular appearance of the tarsal conjunctiva with ptosis, and clear mucus discharge in both eyes, mild rhinorrhea and pharyngeal erythema. The most appropriate management of this patient is.
questions.explanation:
Conjunctivitis treatment

Bacterial Conjunctivitis

  • Erythromycin ointment
  • Polymyxin-trimethorpim drops
  • Azithromycin drops
  • Preferred agent in contact lens wearers: fluoroquinolone drops

Viral Conjunctivitis
  • Warm or cold compresses
  • +/- Antihistamine/decongestant drops

Allergic Conjunctivitis

  • Over – the – counter antihistamine/decongestant drops for intermittent symptoms
  • Mast cell stabilizer/antistamine drops for frequent episodes

questions.text: A 84 year old woman was referred from a tertiary ophthalmology centre with complaint of double vision. Her past medical history include hypertension and Alzheimer's disease. She is not a diabetic. On neurological assessment, she was alert but not orientated to time and place due to her dementia. Upon examination, Light into her right eye causes constriction of her pupil, but not the left pupil. Light shone in her left eye causes construction of only her right pupil. There was no cutaneous lesion on her face in the distribution of the V1 dermatome. Which of the following additional examination findings is likely seen in this patient ?

options.label: A
options.text: Inability to close the left eye

options.label: C
options.text: Visual loss in the left eye

questions.correct_answer: D. Drooping of the left eyelid

questions.text: 20-year-old male presented with a chief complaint of a 3-4 day history of right eyelid swelling, pain, and redness.The patient denied any trauma, discharge, or change in vision, and reported no systemic symptoms or other complaints. On examination, the lower eyelid of the right eye was erythematous and swollen, as well as warm and tender to palpation. There is no conjunctival infection. Visual acuity is normal and the left eye appears unremarkable. The initial management of these patients current condition is.

A 44-year-old man presents to your OPD as he noticed his vision progressively worsen ing throughout the years. He finds mild blurring while reading or looking at his watch. He now has to put items at an arm length in order to see the image clearer. He denies any trouble seeing objects at far distances. He has no history of eye problems. Which of the following is most likely abnormal?

A 65 year old man presents to the primary care physician complaining of bilateral visual difficulty. Over the past one year he has felt increasingly depressed and anxious regarding his progressive localised loss of vision.On physical examination, his vital signs are within normal limits and he appears generally well. Neurological examination shows a subtle resting tremor and increased tonicity. An ophthalmologic examination is significant for small yellow retinal lesions clustered in the macula. Which of the following can be expected on visual field examination?

A 1 year old girl is brought to the hospital for a routine visit. She was born at 35 weeks of gestation, due to preterm labour. The child takes no meditation and has no known allergies. Immunization chart is up to date. Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals a red reflex in the left eye and white reflex in the right. Extra ocular movements are intact, and pupils are equal and reactive to light. Total retinal detachment is seen in the same eye. Corneal light reflex is symmetric. Ultrasound B scan reveals hematogenous subretinal mass with calcification. The most likely cause of the patients examination finding is
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Choice a: Associated retinal detachment can cause leukocoria, but ROP typically affects infant born at < 30 weeks gestation.
  • ↳ Choice c: Uveitis is intraocular inflammation often associated with systemic disease ( eg: infection, juvenile idiopathic arthritis) examination can reveal leukocoria due to inflammatory debris, but eye redness and pain are also expected.
  • ↳ Choice d: strabismus or ocular misalignment can cause an asymmetric red reflex with increase in density in the deviated eye however the corneal light reflex will also be asymmetric not seen in this patient.
  • ↳ Educational objectives: Leukocoria , or white pupillary reflex in an infant or young child should require immediate ophthalmology referral to evaluate for retinoblastoma. Other presenting signs of retinoblastoma include strabismus and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 65 year old male who is the security guard in your hospital comes to the emergency department because of a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye . Five hours ago his experienced a transient loss of vision in the same eye which lasted for 5 minutes . He has hypertension, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia and peripheral vascular disease. He had acute myocardial infarction 6 years ago. His temperature is 36.7°C, RR 16 per minute, pulse is 88 per minute and BP is 146/88 mmHg. On examination visual acuity poor and anterior segment is normal. Fundoscopic examination reveals pale retina and bright red fovea. Suggest most appropriate method of treatment for this patient.

options.label: C
options.text: Occular massage and high flow oxygen

questions.correct_answer: C. Occular massage and high flow oxygen

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady came to the emergency department complaining of extreme pain in her right eye and blurred vision. The pain began suddenly that morning while she was doing household chores and got progressively worse during her drive to the hospital. She vomited once and reports continued nausea.Her eye is hard and red; with hazy cornea; shallow anterior chamber and the pupil is 6 mm dilated and reacts poorly to light.Visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/30 in the left. Likely diagnosis is
